```{r Create Data Frame}

data <- data.frame(x1 = c(7, 2, 1, NA, 9),
                   x2 = c(1, 3, 1, 8, NA),
                   x3 = c(NA, 8, 8, NA, 5))
```

---

Complete Cases:
The complete.cases() function in R identifies rows in a data frame where none of the values are NA (missing). It returns a logical vector (TRUE or FALSE) for each row, indicating whether the row is complete (i.e., has no missing values).
```{r Complete Cases}
complete.cases(data)
```

---

Create subset with only complete rows
```{r Subset}
data_complete <- data[complete.cases(data), ] # 
data_complete
```
- Rows before the comma
- Columns after the comma
[complete.cases(data), ] selects only the rows where complete.cases is TRUE,
but keeps all columns (nothing after the comma)
